definitions.definition: To move , shift , provide something abstract or concrete to someone or something or somewhere.

subdefinitions.definition: To transfer one's possession or holding of (something) to (someone).
examples: I gave him my coat.
I gave my coat to the beggar.
When they asked, I gave my coat.

subdefinitions.definition: To make a present or gift of.
examples: I'm going to give my wife a necklace for her birthday.
She gave a pair of shoes to her husband for their anniversary.
I gave him my word that I'd protect his children.

subdefinitions.definition: To provide (something) to (someone), to allow or afford .
examples: I gave them permission to miss tomorrow's class.
Please give me some more time.

subdefinitions.definition: To cause (a sensation or feeling) to exist in (the specified person, or the target, audience, etc).
examples: It gives me a lot of pleasure to be here tonight.
The fence gave me an electric shock.
My mother-in-law gives me nothing but grief.
it's giving me bad vibes — It's giving me old Hollywood (vibes)

subdefinitions.definition: To give off (a certain vibe or appearance ). [2019?–] ( Compare giving . )
examples: it's giving old Hollywood (vibes)

subdefinitions.definition: To carry out (a physical interaction) with (something).
examples: I want to give you a kiss and a hug.
As mom gave us a long look, I gave a sigh and my sister gave a laugh.
I'd like to give the tire a kick.
I gave the boy a push on the swing.
She gave me a wink afterwards, so I knew she was joking.
Give me your hand.
On entering the house, he gave his coat to the doorman.

subdefinitions.definition: To cause (a disease or condition) in, or to transmit (a disease or condition) to.
examples: My boyfriend gave me chlamydia.
He was convinced that it was his alcoholism that gave him cancer.
The doctors gave me morphine for the pain.

subdefinitions.definition: To present someone to an audience .
examples: Playing for us tonight, I give you The Beatles!

subdefinitions.definition: To propose someone for a toast , used in standard formulations for toasts .
examples: On this happy evening, I give you the bride and groom!

definitions.definition: To provide , as, a service or a broadcast .
examples: They're giving my favorite show!

definitions.definition: To estimate or predict (a duration or probability) for (something).
examples: I give it ten minutes before he gives up.
I'd give it a 95% chance of success.
I'll give their marriage six months.

definitions.definition: To yield or collapse under pressure or force.
examples: One pillar gave , then more, and suddenly the whole floor pancaked onto the floor below.
The master bedroom gives onto a spacious balcony.
His window gave the park.

definitions.definition: To exhibit as a product or result; to produce; to yield .
examples: The number of men, divided by the number of ships, gives four hundred to each ship.

definitions.definition: To cause; to make; used with the infinitive.
To cause (someone) to have; produce in (someone); effectuate .
To allow or admit by way of supposition; to concede .
examples: He can be bad-tempered, I'll give you that, but he's a hard worker.

definitions.definition: To attribute; to assign; to adjudge.
To communicate or announce (advice, tidings, etc.); to pronounce or utter (an opinion, a judgment, a shout, etc.).
examples: The umpire finally gave his decision: the ball was out.

definitions.definition: To grant power, permission, destiny, etc. (especially to a person); to allot; to allow.

examples: The soldiers give themselves to plunder.
That boy is given to fits of bad temper.

main_definition: ( ditransitive ) To move , shift , provide something abstract or concrete to someone or something or somewhere.
secondary_definitions: ( transitive ) To provide , as, a service or a broadcast .
( ditransitive ) To estimate or predict (a duration or probability) for (something).
( intransitive ) To yield or collapse under pressure or force.
( transitive , dated ) To provide a view of.
To exhibit as a product or result; to produce; to yield .
To cause; to make; used with the infinitive.
To cause (someone) to have; produce in (someone); effectuate .
To allow or admit by way of supposition; to concede .
To attribute; to assign; to adjudge.
To communicate or announce (advice, tidings, etc.); to pronounce or utter (an opinion, a judgment, a shout, etc.).
( dated or religion ) To grant power, permission, destiny, etc. (especially to a person); to allot; to allow.
( obsolete ) To become soft or moist.
( obsolete ) To shed tears; to weep.
